history.content: No. I feel like that happens often not to only international students but also American students. It really is hard these days...

children.subject: Just wondering what your dream company was?

Tesla 😎😎😎 Hopefully, if I stay overnight, I’ll meet treElon Musk😁😁😁

FAANG companies didn’t really appeal me and I thought they were more of a status symbol here at Cal.  People love being open about their high monetary offers at Google, Gb, Lyft, Uber , wherever you name it. Just not my type....

Also as another word of advice, don’t overlook soft skills. By being EECS at Cal you’ve already proven you’re capable of enduring one of the toughest and best undergrad curriculum in the world, ESPECIALLY in CS. Don’t forget you’re also a human and not a robot. Find whatever company you really love and if they don’t see the the same fire, tryout some of the SCET classes to see if you would be down to go for the cofounder route and build your own company instead. Merry Christmas!
Wow! Tesla is the dream for me too! Congrats!!

As an Undeclared intended cs person(I got 3.2 and trying to appeal still because I really don’t want the ds major), I’ve been super lucky. Similarly I applied to over 50 internships...similar experience with listing classes and projects from hackathons worth mentioning. I didn’t have any technical experience so I positioned my projects instead of my experiences first on my resume(my experiences are more business and nontechnical oriented)...  only got 2 coding challenges and plenty of flat out rejections. 

And yet I was able to find an internship at my dream company after reaching out to recruiters at that company directly on LinkedIn. You can literally search “software engineering recruit at xyz company” on google or LinkedIn and hunt them down. If you really really want that company, it’ll show with your passion and outshine other possibly “more qualified”(on paper) candidates.  That’s how I made my way so hope this helps. Referrals are one way but that could only get you so far, so go out there and hunt down the recruiters at the company you ready want and truly understand why you really want to work at that company for that specific position. It’ll at least get you an interview.

The real answer is to up your referral game: most job offers people get here at Berkeley are because they knew somebody who could refer them. A lot of times referrals is almost a guaranteed interview for decent CS students.

history.content:
I have been applying (around 50) to all the engineering internships I could find on linkedin and google, and I've haven't heard back or got rejected flat out from most of them. Is it because I am international?

I'm not an EECS god, but I have a 3.55GPA, and a portfolio detailing some of the projects (outside of the classroom) that I've worked on. I also coded my own website.

Are there any tips for international students to find internships this summer? I am really counting on one!
history.subject: International Student applying to Software Engineering Internships
